pages.name: automation

choices.text: Manual deployment, no process or automation
Minimal deployment with ad-hoc scripting, not repeatable
Baseline continuous integration (CI) processing (unit tests, manual testing)
Advanced CI, greater than 90% automated testing, pipelines, approval gateways
Full continuous integration / continuous delivery (CI/CD) from development into production (greater than 90%)
Core build for operating system (OS), only basic (manual) provisioning
Patch and release management (OS)
Automated quality assurance (QA) staging process (standard operating environment, SOE)
Automated OS builds
Automatically managed and provisioned infrastructure through self-service

pages.description:
Change is the new constant, and agile business practices are key to remaining competitive. Automation is often the space most influenced by our technology and methodology.  Please remember that these questions are not based on your aspirational state but on your current workflows.

In this section, please choose the following that best describes your current level of automation.

pages.name: methodology

choices.text: Ad-hoc development approach
Defined waterfall approach
Limited agile development on new projects (not including operations)
Agile development through to production and operations
Agile development in a DevOps culture
Hosting/management only
Defined service-level agreements (SLAs) and IT infrastructure library (ITIL)
Compliance and security auditing
Standard operating environment (SOE)
Full DevOps culture

pages.title: Methodology
pages.description:
In todayâ€™s market, large organizations must rely on more than just technology and tools.

In this section, methodology refers to the way in which you are running your IT projects. Please remember that these questions are not based on your aspirational state but on your current workflows.   In this section, please choose the following that best describes your current level of methodology.

pages.name: architecture

choices.text: Ad-hoc choice of application platforms and tooling, limited understanding of contemporary architectural approaches
Selected vendor technology roadmap, initial understanding of new architectures and designs
Iterative development of existing applications, limited legacy strategy, and beginnings of new development architectures
Focus on new application platforms and limited legacy platforms, well-defined architecture for new development projects and operating models
Holistic and defined overall development strategy, good designs and architectures in place and under regular review
Ad-hoc choice of future platforms
Selected vendor technology roadmap
Focus on maintaining existing infrastructure
Primary focus on new applications
Defined strategy for existing and new architectures

pages.description:
As systems expand, you need to effectively manage your IT environment so all the parts work together to get the quickest return on investment (ROI). The following questions cover the long term architectural motivations, aims, and advances to your current state architecture. Please remember that these questions are not based on your aspirational state but on your current workflows.

In this section, please choose the following that best describes the architecture you currently use.

pages.name: strategy

choices.text: Ad-hoc, tactical, and one-off requirements, poorly understood and communicated strategy
Repeatable requirement-gathering approach, traditional system analysis
Minimal viable product approach
Exploration of multiple approaches to solve business needs
Business value-driven IT innovation, IT working in a collaborative manner with the business
Instances of negative business impact
Good functioning service operations, few unscheduled outages but slow to deploy
Project-based service offerings, no unscheduled outages and rapid deployment
Self-service operations for development and the business
Transparent integration with project IT

pages.title: Strategy
pages.description:
Defining a strategy is one of the most challenging areas for an organization. Often, the ability to interpret and translate business ideas to solutions can be complex.  Please remember that these questions are not based on your aspirational state but on your current workflows.

In this section, please choose the following that best describes the strategy you currently use.

pages.name: environment

choices.text: Traditional programming techniques in a heavily segmented structure
Sporadic agile adoption with limited cross-team collaboration
Multiteam collaboration through formalized communication channel
Early adoption of cross-functional teams and shared delivery goals
100% DevOps collaborative culture with energized cross-functional teams and constant improvement
Standard Unix approach in a heavily segmented structure
Reactive rather than proactive operations teams, water cooler discussions get more done
Collaboration across segments are just beginning, agile is understood, sense of urgency for change is established
Collaborative, smaller, cross-functional teams, open source solutions actively encouraged, communities of practice forming, new collaborative way of working established
100% DevOps collaborative culture with energized cross-functional teams and constant improvement, positive change realized, individuals contributing, open organization understood

pages.title: Environment
pages.description:
In this section, environment is defined as the mixture of staff, culture, training, and skill level within each area. Please remember that these questions are not based on your aspirational state but on your current workflows. 

In this section, please choose the following that best describes your current resources.
